Review Design and applications of hollow-structured nanomaterials for photocatalytic H2 evolution and CO2 reduction Xuli Li a b Ning Li a b Yangqin Gao a b Lei Ge a b * a State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum Beijing, Beijing 102249, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing College of New Energy and Materials China University of Petroleum Beijing Beijing 102249 China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum Beijing, Beijing 102249, China b Department of Materials Science and Engineering, College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum Beijing, Beijing 102249, China Department of Materials Science and Engineering College of New Energy and Materials China University of Petroleum Beijing Beijing 102249 China Department of Materials Science and Engineering, College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum Beijing, Beijing 102249, China * Corresponding author. Tel/Fax: +86-10-89739096 Tel/Fax: +86-10-89739096 Photocatalysis is considered a prospective way to alleviate the energy crisis and environmental pollution. It is therefore extremely important to design highly efficient photocatalysts for catalytic systems. In recent years, hollow-structured materials have attracted considerable interest for application in energy conversion fields owing to their large specific surface areas, improved light absorption, and shortened charge carrier transfer path. Because they contain inner and outer surfaces, hollow-structured materials can provide a superior platform for the deposition of other components. A number of hollow-structured hierarchical systems have been designed and fabricated in recent decades. It is important to rationally design and construct complex hierarchical structures. In this review, general preparation approaches for hollow-structured materials are presented, followed by a summary of the recent synthesis methods and mechanisms of typical hollow-structured materials for applications in the photocatalytic field. Complex hollow-structured hierarchical photocatalysts are classified into two types, hollow cocatalyst-based and hollow host photocatalyst-based, and the design principle and analysis of the photocatalytic reaction mechanism for photocatalytic H2 evolution and CO2 reduction are also introduced. The effects of hollow-structured materials have also been investigated. This review provides a reference for the rational construction of advanced, highly efficient photocatalytic materials. Graphical abstract The synthesis approaches and design principles of hollow-structured hierarchical photocatalysts are summarized. The photocatalytic mechanism analysis of photocatalytic H2 evolution and CO2 reduction is also presented to provide a reference for the rational design and investigation of highly efficient photocatalysts. Keywords Hollow structure Photocatalysis H2 evolution CO2 reduction Design principle 1 Introduction With the rapid growth of the global economy, increasing energy and environmental problems have appeared, such as energy shortages, global warming, and air contamination. It has been reported that reducing energy demand is a key mechanism for alleviating climate change, but such a reduction is not practical for economic growth, especially in lower-income areas [1–4]. Photocatalytic technology, including water pyrolysis, CO2 photoreduction, N2 conversion, and the degradation of pollutants, has attracted significant attention, especially photocatalytic water splitting driven by solar energy and photocatalytic CO2 reduction to obtain useful chemical products, both of which can convert solar energy into storable and transportable chemical energy [5,6]. Influenced by the work of the Fujishima-Honda pioneers in 1972 [7], a variety of semiconductor-based photocatalysts have been developed, including metal oxides (CeO2 [8–11], TiO2 [12–15], ZnO [16–21], perovskite oxide photocatalysts [22–25]), transition metal sulfides (CdS [26–29], Zn x Cd1–x S [30–33], ZnIn2S4 [34–36], Mn x Cd1–x S [37–39]), and nitrides (g-C3N4 [40–44], TiN [45,46]). However, pristine photocatalysts suffer from low energy conversion efficiency and weak stability, especially sulfides such as CdS and Zn x Cd1–x S, which can be ascribed to the fact that S2– is easily oxidized by the photogenerated holes in the valence band. Generally, the inferior activity is caused by the following factors: (1) insufficient light absorption, (2) the high recombination rate of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, and (3) sluggish surface reaction kinetics. A variety of strategies have been reported to promote the photocatalytic performance of semiconductor materials, such as morphology control, element doping, construction of junctions, and decoration of cocatalysts [47–53]. It is well known that performance is closely related to the structures of substances. Hollow-structured materials consist of inner cavities and well-defined boundary functional shells [54]. Their unique structures endow the materials with properties of low mass density, large reaction surface areas, and reduced charge transfer paths, which make them potential candidates in the catalysis and energy conversion fields. Nowadays, hollow nanostructures play a critical role in the structural control of materials [55–57], exhibiting the following advantages in the photocatalysis process (Fig. 1 ): (1) light can be multi-reflected in the inner cavities, which contributes to good light harvesting and utilization efficiency; (2) the large surface area can not only ensure sufficient contact between the photocatalysts and substrates but also supply additional reactive sites to participate in reactions; (3) compared to solid materials, the shells with their short charge carrier transfer paths are more beneficial for the fast separation of photoexcited electrons-holes, thereby inhibiting charge carrier recombination; and (4) the inner and outer surfaces can ensure reactions in spatially separate regions to accelerate the surface reaction kinetics and restrain the back recombination reaction [58]. Materials with hollow structures possess inner and outer double surfaces, which can provide an excellent platform for the deposition of other components. Therefore, hollow hierarchical photocatalysts have been developed through the construction of heterojunctions or loaded with cocatalysts to further enhance their catalytic activity. Heterojunction modification is a powerful approach to promote the separation and migration of electrons and holes by the arrangement of the energy levels of different semiconductors. Depending on the type of semiconductor, heterojunctions can be divided into p-n heterojunctions and Schottky junctions (metal-semiconductor contacts). The heterojunction is constructed according to the energy band matching, which can be classified as Type I, Type II, S-scheme, and Z-scheme heterojunctions [59–61]. Loading cocatalysts has proven to be an effective way to promote the photocatalytic performance of hollow structures [62,63]. The most common cocatalysts in photocatalysis include metals [40,44], alloys [64–68], transition metal phosphates [69–71], transition metal oxides [72–76], and hydroxides [77–79]. In general, metal or metalloid cocatalysts can improve the charge carrier separation and transfer efficiency owing to their lower work function or the construction of Schottky barriers. In our previous research, it was found that AuPd alloys and PtCo alloys possess higher electron capture capability and can stimulate electron transfer from g-C3N4 to the surfaces of alloy cocatalysts owing to their lower Fermi level [80,81]. Moreover, Xiao and co-workers [82] reported that PtPd alloy nanoparticles (NPs) can act as electron traps and provide reduction sites for photocatalytic hydrogen production. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs), including Ni2P, CoP, and MoP, have demonstrated metallic characteristics with lower overpotential for H2 evolution and fast electron transfer ability [83–89]. Analogously, when TMPs are combined with semiconductor-based photocatalysts, the photogenerated electrons tend to transfer to the TMs owing to the different Fermi levels [90]. Du et al. [91] found that MoP exhibited a flat plot in the UV-vis wavelength range, and the valence-band XPS spectrum commonly verified its metallic character. Moreover, the H2 generation rate of CdS increased after decorating it with MoP because of the efficient charge carrier separation and fast reaction kinetics. Cao and co-workers [92] successfully fabricated a metal-phosphide/CdS system, which exhibited superior photocatalytic H2 evolution activity using CoP, NiP, and Cu3P as cocatalysts. Metal-free cocatalysts with relatively narrow band gaps can form heterojunctions with semiconductors through energy band matching or differences in semiconductor types to promote the separation of photogenerated charge carriers [93,94]. For example, Yuan and co-workers [95] fabricated a p-n-type Co3O4/CdS heterojunction by a two-step solvothermal/hydrothermal method. The electron-hole separation of CdS was improved owing to the formation of a p-n junction, resulting in enhanced photocatalytic H2 activity and stability. The photocatalytic activity of TiO2 can also be significantly improved by coupling it with p-type Co3O4 or NiO [96,97]. Based on approaches for constructing complex hollow-structured materials, they can be summarized into two categories: (1) hollow photocatalyst-based materials, such as hollow heterojunction hybrids, hollow photocatalysts decorated with single or double cocatalysts, and hollow hybrids simultaneously decorated with reduction or oxidation cocatalysts on the inner and outer surfaces according to the direction of electron flow; and (2) hollow cocatalyst-based materials, including hollow cocatalysts incorporating other types of photocatalysts in a certain order. Herein, the synthesis strategies of hollow structures are summarized and divided into three categories: hard-templating, soft-templating, and self-templating methods. Although there are some reports on hollow structures, they mainly apply to the use of hollow materials in other fields such as electrocatalysis and supercapacitors. Moreover, many hollow-structured photocatalysts have been developed in recent years. Highly efficient photocatalysts play an important role in the photocatalytic field. However, there are few references regarding the application of hollow-structured materials to photocatalytic H2 and CO2 reduction from the aspects of synthesis approaches and mechanism investigation. Therefore, we summarize recent preparation approaches and synthesis mechanisms of typical single and complex hollow-structured photocatalysts to guide the design of high-performance catalytic materials. Moreover, it has been concluded the photocatalytic mechanism of complex hollow photocatalysts, including the characterization techniques and microstructure analysis methods, to reveal the enhanced photocatalytic activity. 2 Synthesis strategies of hollow-structured materials The synthesis approaches of hollow-structured materials have been rapidly developed since Caruso and co-workers fabricated hollow inorganic silica and inorganic-hybrid spheres in 1998 [98]. The synthesis strategies of hollow-structured materials can be divided into three categories: (1) the hard-template approach, (2) the soft-template approach, and (3) the self-template approach. In this section, we summarize these three strategies in combination with past classic cases and supplement the discussion with reports of hollow-structured materials in the last two years. This review provides a reference for the design of hollow architecture materials used in the photocatalytic field. 2.1 Hard-template method The hard-template method is generally deemed a straightforward way to construct hollow materials [99]. The process of preparing hollow objects is shown in Fig. 2(a) : (1) Selecting and preparing a suitable hard template as the core material, (2) covering the targeted shells on the hard template, and (3) removing the hard template with an appropriate method to obtain hollow structures. Sometimes, it is necessary to adjust the chemical compatibility by functionalizing the surface of the hard template. The final morphology of the material is strongly dependent on the hard-template shape. Therefore, it is important to choose an appropriate object to act as the template. Moreover, the core materials are mainly based on the inert rigid material. For example, hollow spherical materials commonly use colloidal SiO2 and polymer latex colloids as templates because of their tunable size, chemical stability, and simplicity of synthesis (Fig. 2(b)). The preparation of SiO2 is commonly based on the well-known Stöber process, which results in controlled hydrolysis and condensation [100], and polystyrene (PS) NPs can be synthesized by emulsifier-free emulsion polymerization. The formation of nonspherical hollow materials by the hard-templating method is difficult because of the absence of suitable nonspherical templates [101]. Here, we review several common conceptual strategies for covering shells on a hard template. There are various covering approaches to growing exterior shells, including layer-by-layer (LBL), direct chemical deposition, and nanocasting [102]. The LBL method is based on the fact that charged materials with opposite charges are consecutively adsorbed onto flat substrates by electrostatic attraction [103]. Caruso et al. [98] extended the methodology to prepare composite SiO2 nanoparticle-polymer multilayers on colloids, producing hollow-structured materials through selective removal of the core, providing new insight into the fabrication of inorganic and inorganic-hybrid hollow spheres. Direct chemical deposition refers to the direct deposition of the precursors of shell materials onto a hard template to form core-shell nanomaterials via chemical or physical interactions. Sometimes, thermal treatments are carried out to maintain a more intensive relationship between the core and shell. The final process is to remove the hard template to form the hollow structure. The removal of the hard template should be carried out using a suitable strategy such as chemical etching or calcination. However, for the same material, different removal methods likely influence the properties. It is worth mentioning that this method effectively prevents the collapse of the shells after template removal. In conclusion, the hard-template method is the simplest among the three common strategies in concept, is easy to scale up, and has wide applicability [104]. However, there are still some problems that need to be addressed, such as incompatibility issues between the core and shell materials, the energy consumption during template removal, the collapse of the hollow structures, and the absence of a variety of hollow structures [105,106]. 2.2 Soft-template method Soft templates, which mainly consist of polymer vesicles, emulsions, vesicles, polymer micelles, and gas bubbles, are another method used to fabricate hollow materials. Emulsions generally comprise a multiphase system in which an isolated liquid phase is dispersed in a continuous liquid phase; the formed liquid interface is then used as a soft template to fabricate hollow materials [107,108]. These soft templates are easily influenced by the synthesis parameters, including pH, temperature, and solvent. Therefore, it is important to precisely control certain reaction conditions to synthesize the hollow structures. Compared with hard templates, the removal of soft templates is milder. Washing with suitable solvents or evaporation can remove the soft templates, which protects the hollow morphology [101]. The formation mechanism of hollow materials is closely related to the template categories. In this section, we summarize several common approaches to using soft templates to build hollow structures, including emulsion-based, micelle/vesicle-based, and gas bubble-based template methods. 2.3 Self-template method Both methods mentioned above require the introduction of templates during the synthesis process. In contrast to template-assisted approaches, in the self-template process, the target materials are derived from template precursors. Therefore, the self-templating method is a relatively simple procedure with high reproducibility [109]. Self-templating synthetic procedures can be classified into two steps: (1) preparation of the template and (2) transformation of the synthetic template into hollow structures. The formation mechanism of the hollow materials is closely related to the template categories. In the following sections, we summarize several common approaches using self-templates to build hollow structures, including controlled etching, diffusion-regrowth, and heterogenous contraction. 2.3.1 Controlled etching In controlled etching, a specific solvent is chosen to dissolve the inner materials instead of the outer shells, resulting in hollow cavities. In contrast to hard templates, the core and shell are the same material. It is necessary to coat the template with a protective layer in the case of outer shell etching. For example, Hu and co-workers developed a novel strategy to fabricate hollow Prussian blue (PB) with PVP as the protective coating during a controlled chemical etching process (Figs. 3(a)–(d) ). The inner cavity was created by treating the material with HCl solution while retaining the original PB mesocrystals in the presence of PVP [110]. Interestingly, an extra precoating process is not needed if the materials have intrinsic inhomogeneity within the internal sections or they can grow an in situ passivation layer [111]. For instance, Lou et al. [112] explored the formation process of Ni-Fe-mixed diselenide nanocages. Solid Ni-Fe PBA nanocubes were used as self-templates, and hollow nanocages were obtained by treating with ammonia solution. They also found that the etching solvent and time were critical in the reaction process. 2.3.2 Diffusion-regrowth Diffusion-regrowth refers to the central mass diffusing toward the outer region while the outer mass diffuses toward the inner region, each at different diffusion rates, thereby producing hollow structures. As illustrated in Fig. 4 , the formation of hollow NiCo2S4 ball-in-ball spheres is divided into three stages. In the solvothermal reaction process, NiCo-glycerate solid spheres are used as both precursors and metal sources. Thioacetamide (TAA) releases S2– ions to form sulfides. First, a NiCo-glycerate@NiCo2S4 core-shell structure is formed by an anion exchange reaction. Then, the inner metal ions diffuse outward while the outer S2– ions diffuse inward and form a secondary NiCo2S4 shell. In the last stage, a unique hollow structure is obtained upon completion of the anion exchange reaction [113]. 2.3.3 Heterogenous contraction Another formation mechanism of hollow structures is as heterogeneous contraction, which mainly results from nonequilibrium heat treatment. During the annealing treatment process, the organic species is converted into other substances or gases, resulting in weight loss. At the same time, there are two opposing forces acting in opposite directions: a contraction force (F c) and an adhesion force (F a) [114]. Owing to the different directions and sizes of the two forces, a cavity forms during the heat treatment. As shown in Fig. 5 , when heating the core-shell ZIF-8@ZIF-67 crystals, ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 were converted into ZnO/carbon and CoO/carbon, respectively, at the first stage, and small molecules were released at the same time. The adhesion and contraction forces were generated from the rigid CoO/carbon shells and the ZIF-8 cores, respectively. Moreover, the adhesion force assumed a contraction force. To balance the mass loss, hollow cavities were formed in the inner cores. At 700–800 °C, CoO was reduced to metallic Co and nanosized Zn was evaporated, resulting in hollow double-shelled NC@Co-NGC nanocages. The hollow structure accelerated the reaction kinetics, resulting in superior electrocatalytic activity. 3 Synthetic methods of typical single-component hollow photocatalysts There is a close relationship between photocatalytic activity and microstructure, and hollow-structured photocatalysts in particular show great merit. Various methods have been developed to fabricate hollow photocatalysts. In this section, we provide a systematic review of the synthesis pathways of several typical hollow photocatalysts, including CdS, Zn x Cd1–x S, C3N4, TiO2, and CeO2. Moreover, several classical mechanisms of hollow structure formation have been proposed. Finally, we summarize recent reports on related materials and conclude with perspectives on the future trends and the development of advanced hollow materials. 3.1 Hollow CdS Cadmium sulfide (CdS) is considered a significant photocatalytic material owing to its superior characteristics such as an appropriate band gap for visible-light absorption and a suitable conduction band edge potential for photocatalytic reduction reactions [116–119]. However, the photocatalytic activity of pristine CdS is restricted by rapid charge carrier recombination and severe photocorrosion [120–122]. Tremendous efforts have been made to solve this problem over the years. A summary of CdS-based hollow structures is presented in Table 1 . It has been reported that the properties of photocatalysts are closely associated with their morphological features [123]. In particular, hollow-structured CdS has been widely investigated because of its larger surface area, which increases the number of active sites, its light multi-scattering within the interior cavity, which improves the light utilization efficiency, and its shorter charge carrier transport length, which suppresses charge recombination [124–126]. It is well known that hollow CdS can be fabricated by various approaches involving soft-, hard-, or self-template methods. In a previous report, soft-template assisting was applied to synthesize hollow CdS [127–129]. Luo et al. [130] prepared hollow CdS nanospheres using a gas bubble template method. Liu et al. synthesized double-shelled CdS hollow microspheres using a soft-template method, and glycerol-isopropanol emulsion microdroplets were used as the template to form Cd-glycerol precursors, which were subsequently transformed into CdS by reacting with S2– released from TAA. Moreover, single-shelled CdS can be obtained by controlling the reaction time owing to the Ostwald ripening effect [131]. In our previous study, hollow CdS nanospheres [132] were synthesized via a chemical precipitation method using SiO2 as the template to form a SiO2@CdS core-shell structure. Finally, the template was removed using a NaOH solution. In another work, Wang et al. [133] synthesized PS@CdS nanospheres using polystyrene (PS) NPs as templates by a sonochemical process, and the template was removed by etching and calcination (Fig. 6 ). Furthermore, the authors carried out a comparative study on hollow CdS obtained using two different template removal methods. It can be concluded that the template removal method affects the surface micromorphology and crystal structure, resulting in different photocatalytic performances of hollow CdS. Recently, hollow CdS nanostructures fabricated by a self-template approach have attracted considerable attention as this method can effectively avoid intricate template removal procedures. Li et al. [134] applied CdCO3 as a self-template, and cubic CdS/CdCO3 was synthesized by surface vulcanization. Hollow-structured CdS can be prepared by thorough vulcanization. Li and co-workers [135] also prepared hollow CdS nanoboxes by directly sulfurizing Cd-MOF-47 with thiourea based on hydrothermal treatment. As shown in Fig. 7 , S2– ions, which were released from the Cd-MOF, initially reacted with Cd2+ on the surface of the Cd-MOF, resulting in the formation of an outer CdS shell. After 4 h of reaction, the inner Cd2+ gradually dissolved and formed hollow voids. Lou et al. [136] presented a two-step sulfidation approach to fabricate CdS frame-in-cage particles, which used Cd-based Prussian blue analog (Cd-PBA) cubes as the self-template. As shown in Fig. 8 , they first synthesized solid Cd-PBA cubes. It can be seen that the CdS-PBA cubes were partly converted into CdS particles through the sulfidation reaction. In the sulfidation process, the surface of Cd-PBA was covered by PVP. Therefore, Cd2+ first reacted with S2– released from TAA, forming the structure of the Cd-PBA cube-in-CdS particle structure. Finally, CdS frame-in-cage particles with convex surfaces were transformed by a secondary sulfidation reaction. In the second sulfidation process, the internal CdS-PBA was converted into CdS particles, and the diffused ions reacted at the surfaces of the CdS cages, which increased the thickness of the shells and resulted in the CdS frame-in-cage particle structure. Moreover, the photocatalytic H2 evolution of CdS frame-in-cage particles was 13.6 mmol h−1 g−1, which surpassed that of CdS cubes (9.5 mmol h−1 g−1) and CdS cages (11.3 mmol h−1 g−1). These results indicate that the hollow structure is beneficial for hydrogen evolution. 3.2 Hollow ZnxCd1–xS Zn x Cd1–x S, a solid solution of ZnS and CdS, has drawn increasing attention in recent years because of its tunable band gap structure and suitable band edge potential [137,138]. Compared with CdS, the addition of Zn effectively reduces the usage of toxic Cd. Moreover, the photocatalytic H2 evolution performance can be improved by adjusting the value of x [139–143]. However, the development of the Zn x Cd1–x S component is limited by serious charge carrier recombination, resulting in poor photocatalytic performance [144–147]. An effective strategy to improve the photocatalytic performance is to tune the morphology and microstructure of Zn x Cd1–x S. Because hollow-structured materials have the advantages of large surface areas, an increased number of active sites, and short charge carrier transport paths, some investigations on hollow Zn x Cd1–x S have been reported. Li et al. [137] fabricated Zn1–x Cd x S dodecahedral cages via a simple sulfurization and cation-exchange process (Fig. 9 ). In this study, a zeolitic-imidazolate-framework-8 (ZIF-8) MOF and TAA were used as the Zn and sulfur sources, respectively. Hollow ZnS was obtained when S2– was released from the TAA and reacted with Zn-MOF. Because the solubility product constant of CdS is smaller than that of ZnS, hollow Zn1–x Cd x S cages can be fabricated through the ion exchange method, and the Zn/Cd ratio can be controlled by changing the amount of Cd added. As shown in Fig. 10 , Zhang et al. [148] presented a novel strategy to synthesize double-shell hollow-structured Zn x Cd1–x S via a hydrothermal method using hierarchically porous ZnS nanospheres as the template. In the formation process, the double-shell structure resulted from the solution-crystallization process, and the inner voids between the double shells could be controlled by adjusting the amount of Cd(Ac)2. We summarize the hollow ternary sulfide-based hollow structures for use as photocatalysis in Table 2 . 3.3 Hollow g-C3N4 Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) is a promising metal-free photocatalyst owing to the merits of extraordinary thermal stability, unique electronic structure, and low cost [149–151]. However, its practical application is limited by poor visible-light harvesting and fast photoinduced electron/hole recombination [152,153]. Therefore, it is important to find an effective strategy to improve the photocatalytic performance; constructing hollow structures has been certificated to be a feasible way to address these problems [154,155]. Hollow g-C3N4-based structures are summarized at Table 3 . Sun et al. [156] successfully constructed hollow C3N4 nanospheres by a thermal condensation method using SiO2 spheres as the hard template, which was subsequently removed by NH4HF2. In that work, the main use of hollow C3N4 nanospheres was to provide a large platform to decorate other catalysts, thus avoiding self-aggregation. Some studies focused on the construction of tubular C3N4 owing to its hollow and one-dimensional (1D) structure, endowing it with great potential in terms of oriented electron transfer [157]. For example, Huang [158] synthesized C3N4 with a tubular structure by thermal condensation using urea and thiourea as precursors. Wang et al. [159] also reported tubular g-C3N4 by directly heating a protonated melamine precursor. As displayed in Fig. 11 , Gao et al. [160] synthesized millimeter-long nanotubular g-C3N4 and proposed a possible rolling-up mechanism to explain the nanotubular forming process (Fig. 11(e)). Tahir et al. [161] proposed a facile approach to fabricating tubular C3N4 (Figs. 11(a)–(d)). The white powder was annealed after treating melamine with HNO3 in the presence of ethylene glycol. The formation of tubular C3N4 could be ascribed to the breakage of electrically neutral melamine and the existence of ethylene glycol to force polymerization. 3.4 Hollow TiO2 Titanium dioxide (TiO2) exhibits great potential in the field of photocatalysis owing to its environmental friendliness, chemical stability, and competitive production cost [162–164]. Previous reports have indicated that the structural features, covering surface area, particle size, and morphology are highly dependent on the superior physical and chemical properties, thus influencing the photocatalytic performance [165–169]. Table 4 summarizes the applications of TiO2-based hollow materials. Because of the superiority of hollow TiO2, with its large surface area, enhanced light absorption, low density, and good cavity structure, increasing attention has been focused on the construction of hollow-structured TiO2 [170]. Yue et al. [171] successfully synthesized hollow TiO2 using a simple hydrothermal method. Hollow TiO2 spheres were also obtained by a hard-template method using SiO2 as the template, which was finally etched by HF, and the TiO2 shell was formed through a kinetics-controlled coating method [172,173]. Kim et al. [174] reported a one-pot solvothermal approach to synthesize hollow TiO2 nanospheres. The evolution of hollow TiO2 was observed by exploring the change in morphology and structure based on materials with different processing times (Figs. 12(a)–(f) ). It has been demonstrated that the mechanism of hollow-structured formation mainly involves chemical conversion and Ostwald ripening. The chemical conversion mainly included the water generated from the etherifying reaction of ethanol, Ti(OH)4 obtained from the Ti precursor, and the dehydrolysis of Ti(OH)4. The chemical conversion was accompanied by Ostwald ripening, resulting in the formation of hollow TiO2. A schematic of the hollow TiO2 formation is shown in Fig. 12(g). Zhang et al. [175] developed a novel strategy to construct double-shell TiO2 hollow nanospheres, and the fabrication mechanism is demonstrated in this work. First, sSiO2@TiO2 was formed when TiO2 NSs were deposited onto solid SiO2 (sSiO2) (Fig. 13 ). Double-shelled hollow TiO2 (DHS-Ti) was successfully constructed owing to the re-deposition of silica species under the conditions of appropriate pH, temperature, and CTAB. Moreover, DHS-Ti showed a large surface area of 417.6 m2 g−1, which is higher than that of most pristine TiO2. 3.5 Hollow CeO2 materials Cerium oxide (CeO2) with a fluorite structure, one of the most popular rare and low-toxicity earth oxides, has shown great potential in energy conversion and photocatalysis owing to its attractive properties including relatively low cost, high chemical stability, and unique physical properties [176–179]. Notably, CeO2 possesses a unique 4f electronic structure [Xe] 4f 15d 16s 2 and can achieve facile conversion between Ce3+ and Ce4+ oxidation states, which is beneficial for generating strong connections with other materials [180]. Moreover, the rich oxygen defects and exceptional redox properties play a significant role in the surface adsorption of reactants and electron transfer, further promoting the photocatalytic performance. Despite the above merits, pure CeO2 still presents the disadvantages of a small specific surface area and narrow visible-light adsorption, resulting in low catalytic activity. The construction of hollow-structured materials is an effective way to address these problems. In Table 5 , we summarize the CeO2 based hollow structures and other types of hollow materials for photocatalytic applications. Chen et al. [181] fabricated hollow K-type CeO2 nanotubes via a reaction between solid Ce(OH)CO3 nanorods and a NaOH solution. The interior spaces of the K-Type CeO2 nanotubes were composed of segmented voids, whereas T-types were generated through hollowing. Owing to the similar morphologies of T-type and K-type CeO2 nanotubes, the formation mechanism of the K-type can be explored and ascribed to the Kirkendall effect by comparing the T-type and K-type synthesis processes. Hollow CeO2 nanospheres have also been synthesized by a self-templating approach; solid CeO2 nanospheres as the self-template were first synthesized and an FeSO4 solution acted as the etching agent [182]. In our group [183], we fabricated CeO2 hollow structures with a controllable morphology by a templating approach using shape-controlled Cu2O as the template. Cu2O templates with polyhedral, cubic, and spherical shapes were synthesized (Figs. 14(a,b) ). Cu+ as the soft acid is prone to react with soft bases S2O3 2– to form soluble [Cu(S2O3 2–) x ]2– 2x species. Simultaneously, OH− can react with Ce4+ to produce a Ce(OH)4 precipitate. Finally, hollow CeO2 with cubic polyhedral, cubic, and spherical particles was obtained by calcination of the as-prepared Ce(OH)4 samples (Fig. 14(c)). It should be noted that the concentration of CeCl3 must be precisely controlled in the system; otherwise, excessive water or ethanol will induce breakage of hollow nanocages. 4 The fabrication and mechanism investigation of complex hollow heterostructures in photocatalytic hydrogen generation 4.1 Hollow noble metal-free cocatalyst-based heterojunctions for photocatalysis To date, a variety of semiconductors have been developed. However, single photocatalysts still suffer from unsatisfactory photocatalytic performance, which mainly results from the severe recombination of photogenerated charge carriers and sluggish surface reaction kinetics. Loading suitable cocatalysts and constructing heterojunctions has been considered an effective way to reduce the reaction energy barriers and promote photocatalytic H2 evolution. Noble metals or alloys commonly work as cocatalysts [184–192]. However, the high cost and scarcity of noble metals restrict their widespread application. Therefore, the search for efficient non-noble metal cocatalysts has been a hot topic of research in this field. Recently, hollow-structured transition metal-based cocatalysts have attracted immense attention because they integrate the advantages of hollow structures and unique characteristics of transition metal-based materials. The general design strategy involves the growth of suitable semiconductor-based photocatalysts on hollow-structured transition metal-based cocatalysts. Co-based metal chalcogenides with unique optical and electrical characteristics have been used as cocatalysts in photocatalytic water splitting driven by solar energy [193–198]. For instance, CdS dots were embedded in hollow Co9S8 cubes using a one-pot hydrothermal strategy. Compared with pure CdS, the H2 production rate of hollow CdS/Co9S8 cubes improved to 1061.3 μmol h−1 g−1, which was 1.8 times that of solid CdS/Co9S8 [199]. As shown in Fig. 15 , Lou et al. [200] designed Co9S8/ZnIn2S4 heterostructured cages for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. Fig. 15(a) shows the synthesis of the hollow Co9S8 nanocages. The authors used zeolitic-imidazolate- framework-67 (ZIF-67) as the precursor, followed by a sulfidation reaction and thermal treatment to produce Co9S8 cages. Finally, ultrathin ZnIn2S4 NSs were grown on the Co9S8 cages through a solvothermal process (Fig. 15(b)). The hollow Co9S8@ZnIn2S4 sample achieved outstanding photocatalytic H2 evolution activity (6250 μmol h−1 g−1), which can be ascribed to the unique hollow heterostructures, which promoted efficient charge separation and transfer. A control experiment using solid Co9S8@ZnIn2S4 NPs as the photocatalyst was carried out to demonstrate the advantage of using hollow structures for the hydrogen evolution reaction, and the results demonstrated inferior photocatalytic activity (Fig. 15(c)). Electrochemical impedance spectra showed that the Co9S8/ZnIn2S4 hybrid possessed a smaller semicircle than ZnIn2S4, indicating that the addition of Co9S8 can accelerate electron transfer (Fig. 15(d)). In our group [200], a Co9S8 hollow polyhedron sample was fabricated by combining the approaches of self-template and calcination (Figs. 16(a) and (b) ). Subsequently, Zn0.5Cd0.5S nanospheres were deposited on the surfaces of the hollow Co9S8 cocatalysts, which effectively avoided self-aggregation of the Zn0.5Cd0.5S nanospheres (Fig. 16(c)). Co9S8/Zn0.5Cd0.5S exhibited a remarkable H2 evolution rate of 10.9 mmol h−1 g−1 (Fig. 16(d)). Electron spin resonance (ESR) analysis was used to investigate the role of the cocatalyst. As shown in Figs. 16(e) and (f), compared with pristine Zn0.5Cd0.5S, the intensity of the ESR signal peaks decreased with the addition of the Co9S8/Zn0.5Cd0.5S hybrid, which indicated that the photogenerated electrons or holes could be captured by the cocatalysts. As shown in Fig. 16(g), Zn0.5Cd0.5S showed a positive photovoltage, which indicated that the positive charges were transferred to the surfaces of the photocatalysts. After decorating with Co9S8, the surface photovoltage spectroscopy (SPV) signal decreased, which can be ascribed to the positive holes of Zn0.5Cd0.5S on the valence band (VB) were trapped by Co9S8 and not to the upper electrode. The surface work function data were determined according to scanning Kelvin probe microscopy. As shown in Fig. 16(h), the Fermi level of Co9S8 was obviously lower than that of Zn0.5Cd0.5S, and the hot electrons of Zn0.5Cd0.5S transferred to Co9S8 until the Fermi level alignment. Meanwhile, an interfacial built-in electric field was established oriented from Zn0.5Cd0.5S to the Co9S8 species. Under visible-light irradiation, the photogenerated holes of Zn0.5Cd0.5S migrated to Co9S8 and were consumed by the sacrificial agent, effectively promoting photoexcited charge carrier separation. Meanwhile, self-oxidization of Zn0.5Cd0.5S was avoided, and the stability was exaggerated. In a similar study, Zhang and co-workers [202] reported hollow Co9S8/ZnIn2S4 tubes (Figs. 17(a)–(c) ). In contrast to Lou’s strategy, the authors selected Co(CO3)0.35Cl0.20(OH)1.10 nanorod bunches as the precursors to prepare 1D Co9S8 hollow nanotubes (Fig. 17(d)). Analogously, 2D ZnIn2S4 NSs were anchored on the surfaces of the hollow Co9S8 nanotubes, and the composite sample was used for visible-light hydrogen production and reduction of aqueous Cr(VI). The hollow structure can enhance light harvesting and mass transfer, which is beneficial for photocatalytic reactions compared to solid heterojunctions. Moreover, hollow Co9S8/ZnIn2S4 possesses a larger surface area compared to pristine ZnIn2S4, which could provide more active sites for H2 evolution. The hollow nanostructured sample presented an excellent H2 evolution rate of 9039 μmol h−1 g−1 and outstanding reduction activity of aqueous Cr(VI), surpassing that of pure ZnIn2S4 (Figs. 17(e,f)). The results demonstrated that enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen performance can be ascribed to suitable energy level matching, improved light absorption, and efficient separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs (Fig. 17(g)). Yu et al. [202] proposed a new synthetic strategy for hollow CoS x /g-C3N4 nanocomposites, as illustrated in Fig. 18 . ZIF-67 and thioacetamide were dispersed in a g-C3N4 ethanol suspension and then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave at 120 °C for 5 h. In the synthesis process, the opposite zeta potentials of ZIF-67 and g-C3N4 ensured intimate contact via electrostatic attraction (Fig. 18(a)). Meanwhile, ZIF-67 was transformed into hollow CoS x , resulting in a CoS x /g-C3N4 composite (Figs. 18(b,c)). The unique hollow structure not only enlarged the contact area but also facilitated charge carrier transfer and photocatalytic reactions. The CoS x /g-C3N4 hollow sample presented a remarkable photocatalytic H2 generation rate of 629 µmol g−1 h−1, which was 52 times that of pure g-C3N4 (Fig. 18(d)). Density functional theory (DFT) computational calculations were performed to explore the electron transfer pathway. As shown in Figs. 18(e) and (f), the work functions of g-C3N4 (001) and CoS (001) were 4.68 and 4.91 eV, respectively. Therefore, the electrons will transfer from g-C3N4 to CoS owing to the difference in the Fermi energies. Furthermore, the transfer behavior of the charge carriers were validated by the 3D charge density difference (Fig. 18(g)). It can be observed that electrons accumulated at the CoS. The photocatalytic H2 mechanism is illustrated in Fig. 18(h). The electrons of C3N4 on the VB are excited to conduction band (CB), finally transferring to CoS as the H2 evolution active sites to reduce H+ to H2. Meanwhile, the holes in the VB were captured by the sacrificial agent. The hollow structure provided multiple reflections of light to enhance light harvesting. Moreover, the black color of CoS may be beneficial for mass transfer and H2 desorption (Fig. 18(i)). Jiang and co-workers [204] reported hollow bimetallic cobalt nickel sulfide (CoNiS x ) as a cocatalyst to couple with graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4). The synthetic approach was similar to that described in Yu’s report, in which additional Ni was added to the precursor. The H2 generation rate of the CoNiS x -CN composite was 2.366 μmol mg−1 h−1, which was 76 times that of pure g-C3N4. DFT calculations were used to explore the electron transfer behavior. As shown in Figs. 19(a,b) , the work functions of g-C3N4 and CoNiS x were calculated to be 4.76 and 4.84 eV, respectively. The electrons moved from g-C3N4 to CoNiS x because CoNiS x possessed a lower Fermi level compared with g-C3N4, which was demonstrated by the charge density difference shown in Fig. 19(c). It can be seen that the electrons accumulated around the surface of CoNiS x , and the region of g-C3N4 was charge depleted. ΔG H* is an important indicator of H2 evolution. The value of ΔG H*, which was approximately zero, suggests more suitable hydrogen binding on the surfaces of the photocatalysts. CoNiS x -CN displayed a smaller ΔC H* value compared to NiS x -CN or Co-CN, which suggests the benefits of the bimetallic cocatalyst (Fig. 19(d)). The authors also found that the larger specific surface area of CoNiS x -CN resulted in additional active sites for photocatalytic H2 generation. According to the above summaries, it can be deduced that hollow Co-based chalcogenides can use efficient cocatalysts to couple with suitable visible-light-induced photocatalysts, promoting photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity. The effect of Co-based hollow chalcogenides can be ascribed to the following aspects: (1) The hollow structure effectively enhances solar light harvesting owing to the light multiple light reflections and scattering inside the cavity; (2) a larger specific surface area provides a platform to deposit other components and enriches the reaction active sites for photocatalytic H2 reaction; (3) smaller EIS is beneficial for charge carrier separation; (4) a lower Fermi level promotes electron transfer from typical photocatalysts to cocatalysts, promoting carrier separation and contributing to the photocatalytic hydrogen performance. MoSe2 shows great potential for whole-spectrum photocatalytic applications owing to its narrow band gap and very high anti-photocorrosion stability. Abundant heterostructures have been constructed to associate with MoSe2 to promote photocatalytic activity [38,205,206]. Recently, Wang and co-workers [206] presented a novel strategy to fabricate hollow-structured MoSe2/CdSe nanostructures for full-spectrum photocatalytic activity using a simple one-pot solvothermal reaction method. It was confirmed that the formation of the hollow structure was owing to the Kirkendall effect by adjusting the reaction time (Fig. 20(a) ). Moreover, the authors demonstrated the Z-scheme mechanism via DFT calculations. As shown in Figs. 20(b)–(d), the hot electrons transferred from MoSe2 to CdSe until the Fermi level aligned with each other. Meanwhile, an electric field at the interface was formed. Under visible-light irradiation, the photogenerated electrons of CdSe with downward band bending recombined with the photogenerated holes of MoSe2, and a Z-scheme mechanism was constructed. The authors also verified the Z-scheme mechanism based on XPS results. However, under NIR light irradiation, the Z-scheme could not be formed because only MoSe2 could be excited. Graphene (GR) has been used for water splitting and CO2 reduction [208]. However, monolayer GR suffers from inferior photoconductivity characteristics. Lin et al. [209] developed 2D graphene into hollow 3D graphene (HG) through chemical vapor deposition; subsequently, g-C3N4 was rooted in HG, forming hollow-structured g-C3N4@HG through a vacuum-filling thermal polymerization approach. The authors found that the transformation of graphene not only activated the carbon π electrons but also promoted electron transfer from g-C3N4 to HG, resulting in improved photocatalytic H2 evolution. Lou et al. [210] synthesized a novel hollow-structured Co/NGC@ZnIn2S4 heterostructure system (Figs. 21(a,b) shows the synthesis process of the Co/NGC hollow nanocages. The ZIF-8@ZIF-67 core-shell polyhedron was fabricated by an in situ growth method. Co/NGC nanocages were obtained using a high-temperature ZIF-8@ZIF-67 sample followed by acid leaching. The approach of using ZnIn2S4 NSs grown on Co/NGC cages was the same as the abovementioned hydrothermal process. A control experiment was carried out, as shown in Figs. 21(c,d). The hollow structure was beneficial to the reaction, and the reduction reaction mainly occurred on the Co particles. The results demonstrated that hollow Co@NGC is an efficient cocatalyst to promote charge separation and transfer. It also offered abundant catalytic active sites, which contributed to the outstanding photocatalytic H2 evolution activity (Fig. 21(e)). Co@NGC is rarely used as a cocatalyst in the photocatalytic hydrogen field; however, it has been used as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR and OER or as an air electrode catalyst in Zn-air batteries. For instance, Qiu et al. [211] synthesized NC@Co-NGC double-shelled nanocages derived from core-shell ZIF-8@ZIF-67 metal-organic frameworks. The unique hollow structure can prevent metal corrosion and aggregation during the reactions and improve the crystallinity and electrical conductivity of carbon. NC@Co-NGC exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity, comparable to that of Pt and RuO2 species in the ORR and OER reactions. Liu and co-workers presented a novel strategy to synthesize transition metal (Fe, Co, Ni) NPs encapsulated in nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (M/N-CNTs, M = Fe, Co, Ni). The Co/N-CNTs exhibited optimal catalytic activity and stability. In the synthesis process, CoCl2·6H2O and cyanamide were used as precursors and heated at a high temperature. Co/N-CNTs can be obtained by treatment with H2SO4 to remove the unstable and inactive sites [212]. The optimal Co/N-CNT hybrid exhibited superior bifunctional catalytic activity and excellent stability toward both the ORR and OER. The authors reported that the half-wave potential and the overpotential over Co/N-CNT were 0.86 and 0.39 V, respectively, values that were even better than those of state-of-the-art Pt/C and RuO2 catalysts. 4.1 Typical hollow host photocatalyst-based hierarchical systems for photocatalysis Coupling with other components is an effective strategy for improving photocatalytic activity. CeO2-based materials for photocatalytic applications can be mainly classified into three systems: 1) metal@CeO2 heterojunctions, 2) metal oxide@CeO2 heterojunctions, and 3) CeO2 coupled with CdS, g-C3N4, or some other compound photocatalyst. In the system of the metal@CeO2 core-shell heterojunction, the outer CeO2 shell generally protects the inner metal active center and prevents agglomeration. The strong connection between the metal and CeO2 provides a synergetic effect to enhance the catalytic activity. Li et al. [213] synthesized multi-shelled Cu-CeO2 hollow spheres by facile one-step aerosol spray pyrolysis (Figs. 22(a)–(e) ). The Cu species were highly dispersed in the hollow CeO2 and displayed an enlarged surface area. The Cu-CeO2 catalyst exhibited increased catalytic activity and good stability. Recently, Zhang and co-workers [214] fabricated CeO2 with three different morphologies to support Cu particles. Song et al. [215] reported a Pt-enriched@CeO2 hollow nanostructure using Pd@Ag@CeO2 nanospheres as the hard template (Figs. 22(f)–(i)). Pd@void@Pt@CeO2 intermediate products were obtained by the galvanic replacement reaction, which was triggered by mixing the K2PtCl4 and Pd@Ag@CeO2 templates. Finally, the hollow Pt-enriched@CeO2 nanostructure was fabricated by increasing the etching time and reaction temperature. (Pt-enriched cage) @CeO2 showed high catalytic reaction performance and excellent selectivity for cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation. He et al. [216] reported hollow Co3O4@CeO2 composite nanotubes, using hollow Co3O4 nanotubes as the template, coated with a CeO2 shell, which demonstrated efficient CO oxidation performance. Another system of CeO2@MnO2 hollow nanocomposite was fabricated [217], which was different from the design of the Co3O4@CeO2 nanostructure. In that work, Ce(OH)CO3 was first produced as the precursor; subsequently, CeO2@MnO2 was prepared by a hydrothermal approach followed by calcination. The as-prepared materials can be considered candidates for advanced composites; however, the above metal-based materials@CeO2 hollow structure has not been widely applied in photocatalytic hydrogen evolution or CO2 reduction reactions. Combining CeO2 with typical narrow band gap photocatalysts (CdS, ZnIn2S4, g-C3N4) is an effective strategy to extend the light adsorption range and promote charge carrier separation. The general approach is to use hollow-structured CeO2 as a platform for depositing another component. Jiang et al. [218] developed a hierarchical hollow CeO2/ZnIn2S4 nanorod hybrid system. CeO2 nanorods (NRs) were synthesized using the MOF-template method. Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was selected as the precursor and Ce source for Ce-MOF, which can be transformed into CeO2 NRs by calcination in air. Finally, CeO2/ZnIn2S4 was successfully produced via the hydrothermal method (Figs. 23(a)–(c) ). The interfacial built-in electric field accelerated the charge flow between CeO2 and the ZnIn2S4 species, decreasing the recombination of charge carriers and improving the photocatalytic rates of dehydrogenation of PhCH2OH for H2 evolution and PhCHO production (Fig. 23(d)). EPR technology was used to demonstrate the Z-scheme mechanism. It has been reported that the standard potentials of –OH/•OH and O2/•O2– are 1.89 eV (vs. NHE) and –0.33 eV (vs. NHE), respectively. In theory, the electrons and holes in the CB and VB of pristine CeO2 can react with O2 and H2O to generate •O2– and •OH radicals. However, the electrons in the CB of pristine ZnIn2S4 can only reduce O2 . into O2–. As shown in Figs. 23(e)–(f), the results of the signals over the pristine samples were consistent with the theory. As for CeO2/ZnIn2S4, the photogenerated electrons flowed from ZnIn2S4 to CeO2, and the photogenerated holes transferred from CeO2 to ZnIn2S4 according to the Type II mechanism. Thus, .OH radicals were not generated over CeO2/ZnIn2S4 under light irradiation. However, the •OH and •O2– radicals were present over CeO2/ZnIn2S4. In the Z-scheme mechanism, the photogenerated electrons of CeO2 on CB were transferred to the junction and recombined with the photogenerated holes of ZnIn2S4 on the VB. Meanwhile, the strong reductivity of electrons in the CB of ZnIn2S4 and the oxidizability of holes in the VB of CeO2 nanorods were retained, which was confirmed by the presence of obvious signals of •OH and •O2 − in the CeO2 /ZnIn2S4 hybrid (Figs. 23(e)–(g)). It has been reported that S-doped CeO2 hollow spheres coupled with CdS shells exhibit improved photocatalytic H2 generation activity under visible-light illumination with Na2S/Na2SO3 as the sacrificial agent [220]. The coating of the CdS shell can increase the sensitization of CeO2, and the hollow structure of CeO2 can increase the surface area. The photogenerated electrons are transferred from the CB of CeO2–x S x to CdS and reduce H+ to H2, whereas the photogenerated holes are quenched by Na2S/Na2SO3, promoting interfacial charge separation. Wang and co-workers [220] synthesized hollow carbon-incorporated NiO/TiO2 p-n heterojunctions for efficient visible-light photocatalysis using PS nanospheres as hard templates, followed by coating with TiO2 and NiO shells. PS nanospheres not only acted as a template but also provided a graphite carbon source. Recently, hollow-structured CdS@ZnIn2S4 cubes were prepared for pure water splitting under visible-light irradiation [221]. Fig. 24 shows the synthesis of hollow CdS@ZnIn2S4. First, hollow Ag2S cubes were prepared using AgCl as the template, combined with the anion exchange method. Similarly, hollow Ag2S cubes were converted into CdS via cation exchange between Ag+ and Cd2+. Finally, a hollow CdS@ZnIn2S4 hierarchical photocatalyst was obtained by directly growing ZnIn2S4 on the surface of CdS. The authors used X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) to explore the interfacial features of CdS@ZnIn2S4 by analyzing the local Zn atomic environment over CdS and CdS@ZnIn2S4. They confirmed strong interfacial interactions with the formation of Zn atoms in ZnIn2S4 and S atoms in CdS. Moreover, the Z-scheme was verified according to DFT calculations in terms of the energy band configuration. Interestingly, the authors directly confirmed the Z-scheme using SPVM technology. Compared with the hollow CdS cubes, CdS@ZnIn2S4 showed a more significant SPV signal, which indicated a photoinduced vectorial electron transfer path from ZnIn2S4 to CdS. The loading of reduction cocatalysts and oxidation cocatalysts on the same photocatalyst can achieve photogenerated electron and hole migration at the same time. However, the random decoration of the cocatalysts leads to a high carrier recombination probability in the migration process, resulting in low photocatalytic activity. The construction of hierarchical architectures with oxidative and reductive dual cocatalysts has attracted considerable attention. Hollow-structured photocatalysts possess inner and outer surfaces, which can accommodate deposited cocatalysts separately. Therefore, hollow-structured photocatalysts are excellent candidates for constructing hierarchical architectures with spatially separate dual cocatalyst decoration. The synthetic approaches for several primary hollow photocatalysts are summarized in Part II. In this section, emphasis is placed on the design of dual cocatalyst-decorated hollow nanostructures and photocatalytic mechanisms. Cao and co-workers [222] developed a novel strategy to fabricate RuO2@TiO2@Pt hollow spheres with a RuO2 oxidation cocatalyst and a Pt reduction cocatalyst deposited on the outer and inner surfaces, respectively, of hollow TiO2. Hollow TiO2 spheres were synthesized using the hard-template method with SiO2 as the template. The Pt NPs were first anchored on the SiO2 spheres by impregnation with an H4PtCl6 aqueous solution followed by H2 reduction. Subsequently, the TiO2 shell was coated on Pt@SiO2 to form TiO2@Pt@SiO2. RuCl3 was selected as the Ru resource for impregnation of the as-prepared sample followed by heat treatment. Finally, hollow-structured RuO2@TiO2@Pt was fabricated via NaOH etching. Compared to TiO2@Pt/RuO2 or Pt/RuO2@TiO2, RuO2@TiO2@Pt with dual cocatalysts showed the smallest electric resistance and highest photocurrent intensity, which can be ascribed to RuO2 and Pt being located at different positions. The photogenerated electrons were captured by Pt, and holes were collected by RuO2, resulting in a high carrier separation efficiency. Jiang and co-workers [223] presented a method to fabricate Ag and RuO2 on the inner and outer surfaces, respectively, of hollow TiO2 for photocatalytic hydrogen production. Gong et al. [224] synthesized Pt@TiO2@MnO x hollow spheres, with Pt and MnO x loaded on the inner and outer surfaces, respectively, of TiO2 shells for photocatalytic benzyl alcohol oxidation. Sun et al. [225] developed a novel strategy for a hollow Pd@CdS/PdS photocatalyst (Fig. 25(a) ). Fig. 25(b) shows the synthesis process. Pd encapsulated within zeolites (Pd@zeolites) was prepared by hydrothermal reactions and then coated with CdS shells. Zeolites can be removed using a NaOH solution to obtain a hollow structure. Finally, PdS species were deposited on the hollow Pd@CdS using Na2PdCl4 as the Pd resource to react with Na2S. The Pd@CdS@PdS sample showed an outstanding photocatalytic H2 generation rate of 144.8 mmol h−1 g−1, which exceeded the activity of single cocatalyst-decorated CdS (Pd@CdS, PdS@CdS) samples (Fig. 25(c)). PdS possessed a more positive VB potential than CdS; therefore, the photogenerated holes in the VB of CdS were transferred to PdS on the outer surface, which acted as an oxidation cocatalyst. Noble metal Pd species can generally act as reduction cocatalysts, implying that the photogenerated electrons tended to flow from CdS to the inner Pd and reduced water to H2. The opposite transfer direction of the photogenerated electron-hole pairs accelerated the charge carrier separation (Fig. 25(d)). In our group [132], a dual cocatalyst-decorated CdS hollow structure was designed and fabricated (Fig. 26(a) ). Fig. 26(b) presents the synthesis process of Au@HCS@PdS. Au was anchored on the SiO2 nanospheres via thermal reduction. Then, the Au@SiO2 core materials were coated with CdS shells composed of CdS NPs. Hollow Au@CdS can be obtained by the thermal reduction method. Finally, the PdS species was deposited on the surfaces of the hollow Au@CdS to fabricate hollow Au@CdS@PdS through an in situ deposition method just before the photocatalytic reaction. The hollow Au@CdS@PdS illustrated a superior H2 releasing rate of 16.35 mmol g−1 h−1, exceeding those of Au@CdS and CdS@PdS (Fig. 26(c)). The reaction rate was closely related to the apparent activation energies. It was found that the activation energy decreased after the decoration with dual cocatalysts, which indicates that the improved photocatalytic activity can be ascribed to the decreased reaction barriers (Figs. 26(d) and (e)). Moreover, to explore the electron transfer paths, SPV and ESR analyses were conducted. ESR was performed to explore the effect of the cocatalysts in the Au@HCS@PdS system by detecting the signal values of electrons and holes. 2,2,6,6-Tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy (TEMPO) functioned as a radical scavenger of e− and h+ to detect the number of free electrons and holes, respectively. Therefore, more signal changes in the photocatalysts indicated high separation efficiency. Compared with HCS, the signals of Au@HCS or HCS@PdS both decreased, which suggests that Au or PdS can capture photogenerated electrons or holes. Moreover, by combined with the SPV results, the roles of Au and PdS were confirmed. It was confirmed that Au and PdS can act as reduction active sites and oxidation active sites to capture the photoinduced electrons and holes, respectively, promoting the separation of photoexcited charge carriers and improving the photocatalytic H2 evolution performance. (Fig. 26(f)). Xing and co-workers [225] designed a noble metal-free cocatalyst-decorated hollow-structured MnO x @CdS/CoP system. Hollow CdS shells were synthesized using a hard-template method. MnO x NPs used as hole collectors were anchored on the inner surfaces of CdS. Meanwhile, CoP was deposited on the outer surfaces of CdS to trap photoinduced electrons. Compared with pristine CdS, the H2 evolution activity increased from 32.0 to 238.4 µmol h−1 over MnOx@CdS/CoP and showed good stability, surpassing the performance of MnO x @CdS/Pt photocatalysts. Wang et al. [155] successfully fabricated a hollow Pt/HCNS/Co3O4 system with Pt and a Co3O4 species as a reduction cocatalyst and oxidation cocatalyst, respectively, using a hard-template method for water splitting. As shown in Figs. 27(a)–(c) , Pt NPs approximately 3 nm were precisely deposited on the inner surfaces. Meanwhile, Co3O4 NPs of approximately 2 nm were loaded on the outer surfaces of the HCNS. After the rational dual modification, the rate of H2 evolution of Pt/HCNS/Co3O4 increased approximately 10 times that of pristine HCNS (0.3 µmol h−1 H2 and 0.1 µmol h−1 O2); it was also higher than that of Co3O4 and Pt cocatalysts on the outer surfaces of HCNS (Figs. 27(d)–(f)). The authors reported that the elaborate hollow structure design can facilitate multi-hole injection and contact between intermediate species. Moreover, the existence of dual cocatalysts prevented the reverse reaction, promoting H2 and O2 evolution. A Type II heterojunction is an effective way to improve water-splitting performance. Gong et al. developed [227] a new synthesis method for Pt@TiO2-In2O3@MnO x nanospheres for photo-oxidation reactions. Zhang et al. [228] presented a novel strategy for fabricating hollow structures with spatially separated cocatalysts based on a Type II heterojunction (Fig. 28(a) ). Double-shell hollow TiO2/CdS spheres were prepared based on the hard-templating method, where Pt and Co3O4 were separately anchored on the inner and outer surfaces of the TiO2/CdS heterojunction (Fig. 28(b)). The Pt/TiO2/CdS/Co3O4 hollow photocatalyst presented an excellent photocatalytic H2 evolution rate of 2000 μmol h−1 g−1, which was 540 times that of TiO2/CdS. The improved photocatalytic activity can be ascribed to the synergism between the built-in electric field and the spatially separated cocatalysts. As shown in Figs. 28(c)–(f), the built-in electric field was formed at the TiO2/CdS junction. The photoexcited electrons and holes were effectively separated and accumulated on the side of TiO2 and CdS under the influence of the built-in electric field. Moreover, the Pt and Co3O4 cocatalysts decreased the activity energy of the reduction and oxidation reactions of water splitting. Therefore, the electrons and holes were captured by Pt and Co3O4, which further accelerated the interface reaction rate. 5 The application of hollow structures in photocatalytic CO2 reduction process Jiang and co-workers [229] reported hollow structures consisting of Bi2WO6 quantum dots using ethylene glycol as a solvent through a one-pot solvethermal approach. The authors pointed out that the effect of ethylene glycol was not only to assemble the hollow structures but also suppress the agglomeration of Bi2WO6 quantum dots. Compared with bulk Bi2WO6, hollow Bi2WO6 presented better photocatalytic reduction activity of CO2, which can be ascribed to the higher CO2 adsorption capacity and efficient photogenerated charge carrier separation. Lin et al. [230] reported ZnO1–x /carbon dot composite hollow spheres for CO2 photocatalytic reduction under an entire UV-vis-NIR spectrum through a single-step aerosol process. The authors found more oxygen vacancy (OV) defects in the ZnO1–x /C composites than in pure ZnO according to the Raman and XPS results, and the presence of OVs can boost the electron transfer to the CB and promote the photocatalytic activity. Hollow heterostructured g-C3N4@CeO2 with OVs was fabricated by Guo et al. [231] for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. The unique hollow structure and the addition of L-cysteine in the synthesis process effectively improved the light utilization and enhanced the CO2 adsorption capacity. The Ce3+ signal is always coupled with the OV. The obvious EPR signal indicated the presence of OVs in the g-C3N4@CeO2 hybrid. The authors also found that the presence of OVs was beneficial for CO2 reduction. Bie and co-workers [232] presented a novel strategy for fabricating hollow-structured NG/CdS for photocatalytic CO2 reduction (Figs. 29(a) and (b) ). First, the CdS/SiO2 sample was synthesized using SiO2 spheres as the hard template. Nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) was grown in situ on the surface of CdS/SiO2 by chemical vapor deposition using pyridine as the feedstock. The hollow structure was then obtained by NaOH etching (Fig. 29(d)). This approach to fabricating heterojunctions ensured an intimate interface between CdS and NG through coordination between nitrogen and cadmium atoms, which was beneficial for the separation and transfer of carriers, and the hollow structure enhanced the utilization of light reflections. The authors also found that nitrogen atoms in monolayer NG were conducive to the adsorption and activation of CO2 molecules, and the thin shell reduced the recombination and diffusion length of charge carriers, which promoted the yield of CO and CH4 products (Fig. 29(c)). Zhu et al. [233] fabricated hollow Au x @THS@CoO with Au and CoO as the electron and hole collectors, respectively, which spatially decorated CoO and Au dual cocatalysts at the internal and external surfaces of TiO2 hollow spheres (Figs. 30(a)–(c) ). The optimal photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CH4 over Au x @THS@CoO was 13.3 µmol h−1 g−1, which was 60 times that of THS (Fig. 30(d)). There was an obvious SPR adsorption peak centered at 554 nm, which indicates the presence of metallic Au. The authors used the ESR technique to determine the interaction between CO2 and the catalyst (Fig. 30(e)). In N2 atmosphere, the ESR signal was observed at g = 2.0, indicating the presence of oxygen defects over Au2.0@THS@CoO. However, the signal value decreased in CO2 atmosphere, which can be ascribed to the absorption of CO2 at the oxygen defect sites. Moreover, the signal peaks all decreased under light irradiation, which demonstrates that photocatalytic CO2 reduction over Au x @THS@CoO involves the surface oxygen defects of the TiO2 shell. In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra demonstrated that the CO2 − species and H2O acted as the active intermediate and electron or hole scavenger, respectively, in the reaction (Fig. 30(f)). Under visible-light irradiation, the electrons and holes were captured by CoO and Au, respectively, effectively promoting charge carrier separation (Fig. 30(g)). Dehkordi and co-workers [234] synthesized hollow hierarchical g-C3N4@TiO2 spheres using SiO2 and cyanamide as the hard template and precursor of carbon nitride, respectively. Hollow g-C3N4 (HCNS) was obtained by treatment with NH4HF2. TiO2 nanosheets were deposited on the surfaces of hollow HCNS@TiO2 spheres using a versatile kinetics-controlled coating method. Compared with pristine g-C3N4, HCNS and HCNS@TiO2 exhibited larger surface areas, which were conducive to higher CO2 adsorption capacity owing to the hollow structure. Moreover, the hollow structure can achieve multiple light reflections within the interior cavity, resulting in improved light harvesting. The obtained CO2 photoreduction efficiency of HCNS@TiO2 was 11.3 μmol gcat−1 h−1. The enhanced photocatalytic performance can be ascribed to improved light harvesting, multiple light reflections, and enhanced active sites. Li et al. [235] reported hollow-structured Co-based spinel microspheres for CO2 reduction using the self-template method, as illustrated in Fig. 31 . First, hollow NiCo-OH spheres were obtained by a hydrothermal reaction, followed by calcination in air to produce hollow microspheres decorated with 2D NiCo2O4 nanosheets (Figs. 31(a)–(d)). To demonstrate the influence of the unique hollow structure, the authors synthesized NiCo2O4 NPs. It had been found that NiCo2O4 hollow spheres showed larger BET surface areas, which are beneficial to CO2 adsorption and provide additional active sites. As shown in Fig. 31(e), the NiCo2O4 hollow spheres possesses additional OVs. The authors also reported that the presence of OVs can serve as active sites for trapping the photogenerated electrons for CO2 reduction. In the photocatalytic reaction, the NiCo2O4 hollow catalyst exhibited a superior CO generation rate of 15.4 µmol h−1 and good CO selectivity of 84.4%. Zhao and co-workers [236] synthesized hollow BiOBr microspheres using a solvothermal method, as shown in Fig. 32(a) . In situ FTIR was performed to investigate the process of CO2 photoreduction (Figs. 32(a)–(d)). It was found that the peaks of COOH* groups gradually decreased with increasing irradiation time, suggesting that the COOH* group is an important intermediate during the process of reducing CO2 to CO and CH4. It can be observed that OVs in the 120 BiOBr sample (120BB). The signal peak disappeared in the CO2 gas, which can be ascribed to the absorption of CO2 in the OVs. Interestingly, the authors observed that the signals of the OVs were enhanced under light irradiation, indicating that light irradiation was beneficial to the increase in OV concentration. Moreover, OVs may have an effect of lattice distortion in BiOBr and redistribute the charge, as determined by comparing the figure of electron density between BiOBr and BiOBr (OVs) (Figs. 32(e) and (f)). Fig. 32(g) shows the CO2 mechanism over BiOBr. The hollow structure can promote light harvesting because light can achieve multiple scattering and reflection in the hollow voids. Moreover, the unique hollow structure possesses larger surface areas to act as active sites for the CO2 reduction reaction. The thin shell can effectively shorten the transportant distance, which is beneficial for the separation of photogenerated charge carriers. the authors also reported that OVs contributed to the absorption and activation of CO2 molecules, thereby accelerating CO2 reduction. The optimal evolution rates of CO and CH4 over hollow BiOBr were 88.1 and 5.8 μmol g−1 h−1, respectively, values that are better than that of plate-like BiOBr. Bismuth oxychloride (BiOCl) has attracted significant attention owing to its unique characteristics such as good stability, non-photocorrosivity, and great potential in the application of wastewater treatment and water splitting [237]. Recently, Maimaitizi et al. [238] synthesized N and Pt co-doped hierarchical hollow BiOCl (HHBs) photocatalysts via an in situ hydrothermal approach, which was assembled using numerous NSs. The N and Pt co-doped HHBs showed excellent photocatalytic activity, including photocatalytic CO2 reduction and photodegradation of ciprofloxacin and rhodamine B (RhB). As shown in Figs. 33(a) and (b) , the binding energy of the N 1s and Pt 4f peaks at 399.82, 73.36, and 76.54 eV can be ascribed to the Bi–N bond and Pt0, indicating the co-doping of N and Pt on HHBs. The authors also reported improved absorption, which can be attributed to two reasons: (1) the hollow structure with porous architecture resulted in multiple reflections and (2) the N doping and the plasmon effect of Pt. The authors also adopted CO2-TPD to investigate CO2 adsorption performance. As shown in Fig. 33(c), compared with HHBs and N-HHBs, Pt/N-HHBs exhibited the largest peak area, which suggests the highest number of active sites. They carried out CO2 reduction experiments in a 0.1 M NaOH solution. The NaOH solution improved the solubility of CO2 via the formation of HCO3 − and CO3 2– species. It was found that there were no CH4 or CO products, which may have resulted from CH4 or CO being produced only through the photoreduction of CO2 molecules. Fig. 33(d) shows the photocatalytic mechanism of the Pt1/N0.25-HHBs. Under light irradiation, the photogenerated electrons are excited into the CB of the HHBs. The doping of N introduces an impurity energy level and improves the absorption range and photogenerated separation. The photogenerated electrons on the CB of BiOCl can be trapped by Pt, accelerating the separation of charge carriers. Finally, CO3 2– can react with the photogenerated electrons, producing methanol or ethanol. 6 Summary and future perspectives Photocatalytic H2 evolution and CO2 reduction have attracted considerable attention over the last few decades. Therefore, it is critical to design highly efficient photocatalysts. Hollow-structured materials exhibit excellent characteristics for photocatalysis, including enhanced light absorption, shortened charge carrier transfer paths, and large surface areas. In this review, we have summarized the general hollow material synthesis strategies including hard-templating, soft-templating, and self-templating methods (Fig. 34 ). Along with the rapid development of hollow materials, these materials experience various complex structures and morphologies. Synthesis approaches for recent typical photocatalysts (CdS, Zn x Cd1–x S, C3N4, TiO2, and CeO2) with hollow structures have been introduced. The construction of multicomponent materials has shown great potential for improving photocatalytic activity. Therefore, it is important to review the rational design of advanced photocatalysts. Based on the characteristics of hollow materials in photocatalysis, the following types of multicomponent hollow materials can be constructed (Fig. 35 ): (1) hollow cocatalysts to grow photocatalysts; (2) hollow host photocatalysts to decorate with single or (3) dual cocatalysts, including oxidation or reduction cocatalysts; and (4) construction of hollow heterojunctions or (5) hollow heterojunctions to decorate with oxidation and reduction dual cocatalysts. The design principle and advantages of advanced hollow photocatalysts and photocatalytic H2 and CO2 mechanisms have also been explored. Loading suitable oxidation or reduction cocatalysts can effectively separate the charge carriers spatially. It is mentioned that an intimate interface is necessary for fabricating multi-structure photocatalysts, which can ensure fast electron transfer. Moreover, SPV and ESR analysis and DFT calculations combined with experiments have been demonstrated to be new approaches to explore the photocatalytic mechanism in depth. Other applications of hollow structures include CO oxidation, supercapacitors, electrocatalysis, and N2 fixation. For instance, He and co-workers synthesized hollow mesoporous Co3O4-CeO2 nanotubes for catalytic CO oxidation [239]. First, they synthesized hollow Co3O4 nanotubes through a self-templating method, and then Co3O4 was coated with a CeO2 shell. When the CeO2 content was approximately 26.3 wt%, the Co3O4-CeO2 sample achieved 100% CO conversion at 145 °C. NiCo2O4/CeO2 hierarchical hollow spheres were successfully fabricated via a solvothermal approach combined with calcination in air, which exhibited a high specific capacitance and excellent cycling stability [240]. Recently, Li et al. [241] reviewed MOF-derived heterostructures for electrocatalysis, including hollow metal hydroxide heterostructures, hollow metal oxide heterostructures, hollow metal sulfides, metal phosphides, metal selenides, and others. The application of advanced electrocatalytic reactions over hollow materials involves the oxygen evolution reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen reduction reaction, CO2 reduction reaction, and N2 reduction reaction. Zhang et al. [242] synthesized multi-shelled hollow Cr2O3 microspheres through a facile route for electrohydrogenation of N2 to NH3, which exhibited a high Faradaic efficiency (6.78%) and NH3 yield (25.3 µg h−1 mgcat−1) at –0.9 V. Nazemi and co-workers [243] fabricated hollow Au-Ag2O nanocages to convert N2 to NH3 in a pure water system using a photo(electro)chemical setup. The rate of N2 evolution reached 28.2 mg m−2 h−1, and the apparent quantum efficiency was 1.2% at 685 nm. Although some progress has been made in the field of energy conversion, many challenges still exist, and practical application of the developed hollow structures is still in the future. It is still necessary to try our best to promote the development of the field. For the fabrication of photocatalysts, economical, high-performance, stable, and environmentally friendly materials need to be considered for further large-scale applications. However, exploration of the photocatalytic mechanism is equally important. The investigation of the mechanism is not only beneficial to the design of highly efficient photocatalysts but also contributes to the development of characterization techniques and microstructure analysis. We hope that this review provides a reference for the fabrication of novel hollow materials and the exploration of photocatalytic H2 and CO2 reduction mechanisms in depth. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalysis is considered a prospective way to alleviate the energy crisis and environmental pollution. It is therefore extremely important to design highly efficient photocatalysts for catalytic systems. In recent years, hollow-structured materials have attracted considerable interest for application in energy conversion fields owing to their large specific surface areas, improved light absorption, and shortened charge carrier transfer path. Because they contain inner and outer surfaces, hollow-structured materials can provide a superior platform for the deposition of other components. A number of hollow-structured hierarchical systems have been designed and fabricated in recent decades. It is important to rationally design and construct complex hierarchical structures. In this review, general preparation approaches for hollow-structured materials are presented, followed by a summary of the recent synthesis methods and mechanisms of typical hollow-structured materials for applications in the photocatalytic field. Complex hollow-structured hierarchical photocatalysts are classified into two types, hollow cocatalyst-based and hollow host photocatalyst-based, and the design principle and analysis of the photocatalytic reaction mechanism for photocatalytic H2 evolution and CO2 reduction are also introduced. The effects of hollow-structured materials have also been investigated. This review provides a reference for the rational construction of advanced, highly efficient photocatalytic materials.

coredata.dc:title: Design and applications of hollow-structured nanomaterials for photocatalytic H2 evolution and CO2 reduction
